intro: Erigeron formosissimus var. viscidus, commonly known as the viscid fleabane, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk flowers. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky soils. Its leaves are covered in a fine, sticky layer of hairs, giving it the common name "viscid." The flowers bloom in the summer, producing a showy display that attracts pollinators like bees and butterflies.
